Yeah. Just going back to that securitization, the 2 billion add-back, is this number currently included in the 3.5 billion deduction from Basel II as per slide 23? Or is there -- do you see an increase in that deduction before it gets netted out under Basel III?
You mean compared to the slide 23, that's correct?
Yeah.

Yes. This 2 billion will be part – well it's not exactly the same figure because we have protected by 2012. But in the 3.5 billion deduction of Basel II, part of that is linked definitely to securitization and this will be reduced yes.
Yeah the last question was basically to understand how -- why the allocated equity in the legacy asset division increased so much if the absolute exposure --

I think – so I think I answer as the CIB has a whole level, this means that while the CIB has a whole level, capital allocation has increased essentially due to legacy asset because our allocation internally is not just 7% of the risk weighted assets, but also we had, to this capital allocation 50% of the deduction linked to securitization. So that's why in the legacy assets you have this inflation and this means that it is the beginning of the quarter. So this means that during the second quarter from 31st of March to 30th of June, we're seeing certain rate certain configuration which has led to additional reduction.
Okay. Thank you.
Next question is from Mr. James Hike Primerica Investment. Please go ahead.

Yes, please. I've got one minor Basel III question, the bigger ones have been answered and one exposure question. The Basel III is, can you explain in terms of the floors or are the calculations you give are without with floors? What are your assumptions for the full implementation of Basel III there? Are you saying that for the retail portfolio, the floors will be lifted? That's the first one. Secondly, on exposure, could you give us an update on the CBS disclosures, aren't particularly on the more sensitive markets like countries – sovereigns like Greece and Portugal, given the restart of a sort of a sovereign crisis mark 3 or mark 4 where we are right now.
James, I didn't catch the first point on the floor.
Yeah. Your current -- in your disclosure of where we are on -- your current calculation or the current Basel.
On the current calculation, which is a floor, it will disappear it is a fact that...
[Question Inaudible] .
You cannot go below 20% of the previous calculation of the Basel 1.
Right.
So the benefit of Basel II compared to Basel I cannot exceed a reduction of more than 20%, besides. ..
That's right, that's where we are on the .

Let's say reiterated for the shares, so we are slightly below 20% gains. So this means that in the pure calculation, we will be a cut at 20%. But in our disclosure as we feel that also we see at this rate there would be a risk-weighted inflation. And so, compared to Basel I, the floor will no longer be earthed. We have no longer any impact on the Basel III.
Regarding your second question on the --.
Greece, Portugal etc.

Well, we never give, let's say, detail of our exposure in country, except for Greece. On Greece let's say the exposure is roughly stable for the banking book compared to where it was at the end of June. And on the trading, let's say, it has been reduced. Altogether, I would say we are still in the same order of magnitude on the so called PIKS including Italy. So we said that it was something around 10 billion including banking and trading. So we have no big shift compared to end of June. Also, you will see well -- it's more in the calculation of the book value that the other comprehensive income on the available for sale has shrink during the quarter compared to its level of end of June and also compared to its level of the 1st of Jan, showing that exposure has been well managed and there is no, let's say, hidden losses in the AFS.
Thank you very much.
You're welcome. I think there is two last questions.
We have a follow-up question from Mr. Omar Fall from UBS. Please go ahead.

Hi, again, Didier. Sorry, just a follow-up on the insurance deduction, the insurance capital deduction on the financial conglomerates, why do you feel confident in using the financial conglomerates directors when, for example, one of your very close peers is certainly not budgeting for that. Is there some guidance that you have received? Why you are comfortable using that?

But Omar, I think what we have said there is a directive that was voted recently which is on the financial conglomerate. A lot of people have think about how we can let's say treat such groups. It is up and running, and I would say there is proposal. We just want to apply it and thus, I think that why we should we change something which has been decided recently just to address this question. So that's the point.
Okay. No problem.
Okay.
Thanks a lot.
Thank you.
The last question is from Mr. Guillaume Tiberghien from Credit Suisse. Please go ahead.

Yes, thanks. I just wanted to do a small follow-up on domestic retail banking revenues. I can appreciate that it's a bit early to give a guidance -- detailed guidance for 2011. But maybe, can you give us some comfort that even with low rates and with less ability to price for services, we can expect positive revenues at least.
Did we ever report a negative growth of revenues in French retail.
There's is a first for everything.

Yes. But when look at the interest rate environment, I remember when I used to be investor relation in 2004, there was a flattening of the yield curve, rates were relatively low and despite that, we were able to deliver positive growth. So if you want just a start off guidance, I can tell you that revenue will grow next year compared to this year, Guillaume, if it was your main worries.
Thank you very much.
We will update you more into detail at the time of the full-year results.
Okay. Thank you.

I think that we have no other questions. So, I would like to thank you for this very proactive and long -- I expect not too long for you -- Q&A session. I think that what we should be able to remember from this third quarter results is the good performance of all of our activities. The fact that the group, as I said during my presentation, is continuing to transform itself. We have already also made some shift in the business model so with the investment in systematic equities that will be booked in the P&L as from the fourth quarter. Also, the divestment of ECS that was closed last week, we feel that we are showing a further restoration of the rebound of the group. And also, we wanted to provide you in a transparent manner a vision of what we could expect on the Basel III for . I thank you again for your attention. And certainly we will have occasion to discuss in the coming weeks, in the coming months about this subject.
Thank you and have a good day. Bye, bye.
Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes the conference call. Thank you all for attending. You may now disconnect.
